properties.title: William the Conqueror
properties.content: William the Conqueror born in Falaise, Normandy
properties.attribution: Cleveland Museum of Art, CC0, via Wikimedia Commons

properties.title: Battle of Fulford
properties.content: A battle between King Harold Godwinson’s northern earls and a Viking army led by Harald Hardrada. This led to the Battle of Stamford Bridge, weakening England before the Norman invasion.
properties.alt_text: Battle of Fulford, By Matthew Paris
properties.attribution: Matthew Paris, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

properties.title: Battle of Stamford Bridge
properties.content: Harold Godwinson defeated the Viking forces of Harald Hardrada, ending the Viking threat. However, Harold’s forces were weakened before the upcoming Battle of Hastings.
properties.alt_text: Battle of Stamford Bridge, 1870, by Peter Nicolai Arbo
properties.attribution: Peter Nicolai Arbo, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

properties.title: Battle of Hastings
properties.content: William the Conqueror defeated King Harold II, leading to the Norman Conquest of England and William's eventual coronation as king.
properties.attribution: Myrabella, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

properties.title: Coronation of William the Conqueror
properties.content: William I ("the Conqueror") was crowned King of England at Westminster Abbey after his victory at the Battle of Hastings.
properties.attribution: Matthew Paris, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

properties.title: Rebellions in Northumbria
properties.content: Multiple uprisings by Northumbrian nobles and locals against Norman rule. These rebellions, including the killing of Norman Baron Robert de Comines, were crushed by William, culminating in the Harrying of the North.
properties.image: media/Robert Batty - Durham; the Castle and Cathedral from the River - 9338.jpg
properties.attribution: Robert Batty, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

properties.title: Henry I Born
properties.content: Henry I born in Selby, Yorkshire, England
properties.alt_text: Selby, England - Site of Williams birth
properties.attribution: derek dye, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

properties.title: Harrying of the North
properties.content: A brutal campaign by William the Conqueror to suppress rebellions in Northumbria. Villages were burned, crops destroyed, thousands were killed or displaced devastating the region for years. The accompanying famine killed 100,00.
properties.attribution: Internet Archive Book Images, No restrictions, via Wikimedia Commons

properties.title: William orders Battle Abbey Built
properties.content: Pope Alexander II orders William to do penance for killing so many during his conquest, so William commisions the building of Battle Abbey.
properties.attribution: WyrdLight.com, CC BY-SA 3.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

properties.title: Establishment of Durham Prince-Bishopric
properties.content: The Bishop of Durham was granted both secular and religious authority over the region, becoming a semi-independent prince-bishopric. This helped secure Norman control over northern England.
properties.attribution: Joseph Mallord William Turner, CC0, via Wikimedia Commons

properties.title: Revolt of the Earls
properties.content: A rebellion by three English earls, Ralph de Gael, Roger de Breteuil, and Waltheof of Northumbria, against William the Conqueror. The revolt was quickly suppressed, cementing Norman control over England.
properties.alt_text: Ralph de Gael, a leader of the revolt.
properties.attribution: By Matilda Maria Blake - Project Gutenberg's The Siege of Norwich Castle, by Matilda Maria BlakeThis eBook is for the use of anyone anywhere at no cost and withalmost no restrictions whatsoever. You may copy it, give it away orre-use it under the terms of the Project Gutenberg License includedwith this eBook or online at www.gutenberg.org/licenseTitle: The Siege of Norwich Castle: A story of the last struggle against the ConquerorRelease Date: October 24, 2012 [EBook #41168]Language: English, Public Domain, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=126355547

properties.title: Beheading of Waltheof
properties.content: Waltheof, Earl of Northumberland and Last Anglo-Saxon Earl was beheaded. It is said his wife, Judith, neice of William the Conqueror, who disliked and did not trust him, told of another plot to revolt to Archbishop LaFranc, who reported it to William. It is said after beheading his head was found reattached to his body in his coffin. A cult of martydom sprang up around him.
properties.attribution: Thorvaldsson, CC BY-SA 3.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

properties.title: Construction of the Tower of London
properties.content: Begun under William I, the Tower of London was built to reinforce Norman dominance and control over London and England.
properties.attribution: Thomas Hearne, CC0, via Wikimedia Commons

properties.title: Building of Newcastle Castle
properties.content: Robert Curthose, son of William the Conqueror, built the original wooden motte-and-bailey castle at Newcastle to fortify the area and establish Norman dominance over the northern frontier.
properties.attribution: L. Connell, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

properties.title: Marriage of Stephen Henry Bloise to William I daughter, Adela.
properties.content: William I daughter, Adela, marries Sephen Henry of Bloise.
properties.attribution: By Unknown author - http://numerique.bibliotheque.toulouse.fr/collect/general/index/assoc//ark:/74899/B315556101_MS0450_190R.dir/img0064_screen.jpeg, Public Domain, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=9472395

properties.title: Domesday Book
properties.content: Commissioned by William the Conqueror in 1085 in Gloucester, the Domesday Book was a comprehensive survey of land and resources across England. It allowed William to assess wealth, land ownership, and taxes owed, consolidating Norman control over England and helping enforce Norman authority through taxation and feudal obligations.
properties.attribution: Birmingham 1066-1625, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

properties.title: Death of William the Conqueror
properties.content: William I died at the Priory of St. Gervais in Rouen, Normandy, and his son, William II, became King of England. The succession stabilized Norman rule, but tensions remained, particularly in the northern regions.
properties.attribution: By Sophie de Bourgoing - Own work, CC BY-SA 3.0, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=19322082

properties.title: William II Coronated after his father's death.
properties.content: William II (Rufus) coronated shortly after his father's death.
properties.attribution: Charles Gore, CC0, via Wikimedia Commons

properties.title: Rebellion of 1088
properties.content: Nobles led by Bishop Odo of Bayeaux revolt against William Rufus on behalf of Robert Curthose to unite England and Normandy. Robert's failure to show, William Rufus' bribes, and capture of Odo at Pevesney Castle led to a quick end to the revolt.
properties.attribution: By Samuel & Nathaniel Buck - http://archexpo.net/fr/contenu/la-baie-de-pevensey-gravure-de-francis-jukes#.U2lCC4FdXAx, Public Domain, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=32627063

properties.title: William II’s Campaigns
properties.content: William II (Rufus) launched military campaigns to secure Northumberland and push back Scottish forces. His success at capturing Carlisle helped solidify Norman control over the northern border.
properties.attribution: Edward Francis, CC BY 3.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

properties.title: Stephen of Blois is born.
properties.content: Stephen of Blois is born to Adela and Stephen Henry Blois.
properties.attribution: By Larisa sklar giller - Own work, CC BY-SA 4.0, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=52650162

properties.title: Battle of Alnwick
properties.content: Scottish King Malcolm III was killed during a raid into Northumberland at Alnwick. This defeat secured Norman control over the northern border and weakened Scottish ambitions in the region.
properties.attribution: By Forman Armorial (produced for Mary, Queen of Scots) - This image is available from the National Library of Scotland under the sequence number or Shelfmark ID Adv.MS.31.4.2, fol.5r., Public Domain, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=1409450

properties.title: Construction of Alnwick Castle
properties.content: Alnwick Castle was built by Yves de Vescy as a defensive stronghold for Norman England against Scottish incursions. It played a key role in the defense of Northumberland and remains a symbol of Norman power.
properties.attribution: By Alexander Francis Lydon (1836-1917) - book County Seats of The Noblemen and Gentlemen of Great Britain and Ireland, Public Domain, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=3850893

properties.title: Robert Curthose and Stephen of Blois go on First Crusade
properties.content: Robert Curthose and Stephen Henry of Bloise, father of the later king of England, join forces and meet other rulers in Constantinople for the First Crusade.
properties.attribution: By Wilhelm Salzenberg (* 20. Januar 1803 in Münster; † 23. Oktober 1887 in Vernex-Montreux, Schweiz)Edited by Verlag von Ernst & Korn Berlin, 1854 - [1], Public Domain, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=98552725

properties.title: Robert Curthose meets wife, Sybilla de Conversano
properties.content: Robert Curthose meets Sybilla de Conversano while in Apulia and falls in love awaiting transport to the first crusade. She'll become his future wife.
properties.attribution: By fol. 317v, Public Domain, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=354555

properties.title: Robert Curthose and Stephen of Blois at Nicea.
properties.content: Robert Curthose and Stephen Henry of Bloise join the main body of troops as the seige Nicea.
properties.attribution: By Anonymous - BNF Français 779 f.21v bnf.fr[1][2], Public Domain, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=9926546

properties.title: Seige of Antioch.
properties.content: Robert Curthose, Stephen Henry of Blois, and other crusaders seige Antioch. Stephen Henry of Bloise departs back for France shortly thereafter.
properties.alt_text: Robert Curthose at the Siege of Antioch
properties.attribution: By Jean-Joseph Dassy - Painting by J.J. Dassy, 1850, "Croisades, origines et consequences.", Public Domain, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=3112301

properties.title: Siege of Ma’arrat al-Numan
properties.content: Crusaders, including Robert Curthose, takes part in the Siege of Ma’arrat al-Numan, where lack of provisions, desperation, and possibly psychological warfare lead to cannibalism of the muslim dead.
properties.alt_text: Robert Curthose takes part in the Siege of Ma’arrat al-Numan, where lack of provisions, desperation, and possibly psychological warfare lead to cannibalism of the muslim dead.
properties.attribution: By Unknown author - Les Croisades, Origines et consequences, by Claude Lebedel ISBN 2737341361, Public Domain, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=3200268

properties.title: Seige of Jerusalem.
properties.content: Crusaders and Robert Curthose seige the Holy City of Jerusalem.
properties.attribution: By Unknown author - Ökumenisches Heiligenlexikon; Quelle dort: "Miniatur aus dem 13. Jahrhundert: Belagerung und Eroberung von Jerusalem, in der Bibliothèque Nationale in Paris", Public Domain, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=3853070

properties.title: Battle of Ascalon
properties.content: Crusaders including Robert Curthose defeat Egyptian forces at Ascalon, temporarily ensuring their control of Jerusalem.
properties.attribution: By Victory Schnetz - http://collections.chateauversailles.fr/#57714ebb-1b3b-4095-afc0-7623c2e8ebf5, Public Domain, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=118325008

properties.title: Death of William II (Rufus) at New Forest
properties.content: William II was killed in a hunting accident in the New Forest, and his younger brother, Henry I, ascended to the throne.
properties.attribution: Grandes Chroniques de France, CC BY-SA 4.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

properties.title: Coronation of Henry I
properties.content: Henry I was crowned king following the death of his brother, William II. He established legal and administrative reforms that influenced English law.
properties.alt_text: Henry I coronated at Westminster Abbey
properties.attribution: Unknown author, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

properties.title: Marriage of Henry I to Matilda of Scotland
properties.content: Henry I married Matilda of Scotland, uniting the Norman and Anglo-Saxon royal lines, helping to legitimize Norman rule over England.
properties.attribution: By Anonymous - http://molcat1.bl.uk/IllImages/Kslides%5Cmid/K066/K066599.jpg, Public Domain, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=9643622

properties.title: Robert Curthose lands in Portsmouth with support of Anglo-Norman Barons attempting to oust Henry I, but to no avail.
properties.content: Robert Curthose lands in Portsmouth with support of Anglo-Norman Barons attempting to oust Henry I, but to no avail.
properties.attribution: By JohnArmagh - Own work, CC0, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=16374436

properties.title: Stephen Henry of Blois dies
properties.content: Stephen Henry of Blois dies, probably at Ascalon, after the Battle of Ramblah in the the Second Crusade.
properties.attribution: By Roger de Gaignières - http://lamop.univ-paris1.fr/baudin/images/etienne-henri.jpg, Public Domain, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=8381172

properties.title: Henry I defeats Robert Curthose at the Battle of Tinchebray
properties.content: Henry I defeats his brother Robert Curthose at the Battle of Tinchebray
properties.attribution: By Rohan Master - [1], [2], [3], Public Domain, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=9477396

properties.title: Robert Curthose imprisoned and spends 20 years in Devizes Castle.
properties.content: Robert Curthose imprisoned and spends 20 years in Devizes Castle.
properties.attribution: By Brian Robert Marshall, CC BY-SA 2.0, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=36437299

properties.title: Henry faces challenges to his French lands from Robert's son Clito and Louis VI of France
properties.content: Henry I faces challenges to his French realm from William Clito, Curthose's son, and Louis VI of France that culminate in the Battle of Brémule.
properties.attribution: Unknown author, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

properties.title: White Sail
properties.content: William Adelin and Half of the Norman nobility sink in the ship the 'White Sail' crossing the English Channel.
properties.alt_text: William Adelin, who died on the White Ship in Harfleur Harbour
properties.attribution: By Anonymous - http://molcat1.bl.uk/IllImages/Kslides%5Cmid/K066/K066599.jpg, Public Domain, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=9643675

properties.title: Robert Curthose dies after spending his last 6 years in the Cardiff Castle.
properties.content: Robert Curthose spends his final years at Cardiff Castle and dies in 1134, a year before Henry.
properties.alt_text: Cardiff Castle, site of Robert Curthose death.
properties.attribution: Paul Sandby, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

properties.title: Henry I Dies
properties.content: Henry I dies at Saint-Denis-en-Lyons, Normandy, France
properties.attribution: By Medieval artists - British Library manuscripts blog, Public Domain, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=18090729

properties.title: Stephen of Blois claims the throne.
properties.content: Stephen of Blois claims the throne with the help of his brother Henry, Bishop of Winchester and Abbott of Glastonbury. He was crowned by William de Corbeil, Archbishop of Canterbury and powerful supporter.
properties.attribution: By Matthew Paris - Ms 6712 (A.6.89), fol.133rThis scan from http://images.bridgeman.co.uk/cgi-bin/bridgemanImage.cgi/400wm.CHL.8579020.7055475/206579.jpg, originally from Flores Historiarum (see Edmund King, "King Stephen" (2010), Yale University Press, illustration 5.), Public Domain, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=8099785

properties.title: Robert of Gloucester rebels against Stephen, seizing Bristol.
properties.content: Robert of Gloucester seizes Bristol.
properties.alt_text: Robert of Gloucester rebels along with other nobels of behalf of Matilda. He seizes Bristol.
properties.attribution: By Robert Ricart - From the folio Ricart's Maiores Kalendar and The Lord Mayors Calendar whose physical copy is at Bristol Archives, B Bond Warehouse, Smeaton Road, Bristol BS1 6XN. The document is reference number 04720 in the Office's catalogue., Public Domain, https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?curid=34425323

properties.title: Battle of Standard
properties.content: Scottish soldiers invade from the North under King David I, taking most of Northumberland except Wark and Barmburgh. Atrocities are notably horrendous in this invasion and include dismembering and enslaving of the local Northumbrians by Scots. They continue into Yorkshire but are defeated at the Battle of Standard by Stephen's forces under the command of William of Aumale.
properties.attribution: The original uploader was Deacon of Pndapetzim at English Wikipedia.(Original text: Unknown), Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

properties.title: Empress Matilda arrives at Arundel
properties.content: Empress Matilda arrives at Arundel joining forces with her half-brother Robert of Gloucester.
properties.attribution: By Internet Archive Book Images - https://www.flickr.com/photos/internetarchivebookimages/14763983902/Source book page: https://archive.org/stream/seriesofpictures04morr/seriesofpictures04morr#page/n5/mode/1up, No restrictions, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=43928002

properties.title: Battle of Lincoln
properties.content: Matilda's forces capture King Stephen at the Battle of Lincoln.
properties.alt_text: The Battle of Lincoln in the Historia Anglorum
properties.attribution: By Unknown author - The British Library Catalogue of Illuminated Manuscripts, Public Domain, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=9059427

properties.title: Rout of Winchester
properties.content: The Army of Stephen under his wife Matilda of Boulogne, Henry of Blois, and William Ypres faced off against an army led by Empress Matilda and Robert of Gloucester. The imprisoned King's forces arrived to relieve the seige of Winchester by Empress Matilda. They were cutoff from supplies, retreated, and Robert of Gloucester was taken prisoner.
properties.alt_text: Empress Matilda, who led her husbands army.
properties.attribution: By PurpleHz - Own work; alternative at http://imagesonline.bl.uk/imagemap/?cat_id=44&last_cat_id=4&level=2&page=30&search=Events+-and-+Movements+(Historical)&selectedLevels[0]=Historical, Public Domain, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=1378038

properties.title: Exchange of Stephen of Blois for Robert Gloucester
properties.content: A prisoner exchange is agreed between the rival forces which includes King Stephen for the Empress Matilda's brother, Robert of Gloucester.
properties.alt_text: Robert of Gloucester and his wife, he was traded for Stephen
properties.attribution: By Monks of Tewkesbury Abbey, c. 1500-1525 - Bodleian Library Manuscript, Oxford: "Founders' and benefectors' book of Tewkesbury Abbey", (Top. Gloucester, d. 2) folio 15 recto, [1] made in Tewkesbury c.1500-1525, Public Domain, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=32083743

properties.title: Seige of Oxford
properties.content: Oxford Castle is beseiged and Matilda has to flee across the Thames dressed in white to blend in with the snow.
properties.attribution: Unknown Author, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

properties.title: Battle of Wilton
properties.content: An army under Robert of Gloucester attacked Wilton Abbey defeating the army burning and looting the Abbey and nearby houses. His Stewart, William Martel, and his forces delayed Robert's forces giving the king time to escape. William Martel was captured and Sherborne Castle was given to Robert of Gloucester to secure William Martel's release.
properties.attribution: By Jan van der Crabben (Photographer) - Own work, CC BY-SA 2.0, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=304385

properties.title: Seige of Wallingford
properties.content: The seige of Wallingford ended in a stalemate but prompted negotiations.
properties.attribution: U1097x, CC BY-SA 4.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

properties.title: Battle of Malmesbury
properties.content: Facing off at the River Avon at Malmesbury, Stephen yielded, leading soon after to the Treaty of Wallingford.
properties.attribution: Arpingstone, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

properties.title: Treaty of Wallingford
properties.content: Treaty of Wallingford recognized Henry of Anjou, Matilda's son, as heir to Stephen leading to the end of the Anarchy.
properties.attribution: By Sciencebloke at the English language Wikipedia, CC BY-SA 3.0, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=3651545
